section.title: Easily Confused Words
section.para: This section identifies some easily confused words and how to choose the correct term for your situation.

formalpara.title: Affect and Effect
formalpara.para: Each of these words can be used as a verb or a noun, but they are not always interchangeable.

listitem.para: n. Refers to the emotional impact of an action. Unless you are writing a psychology article, this is unlikely to be the choice for you.
v. Means to have an influence on something, or to cause something to change.
n. Refers to the result of some action. For example, "the team members discussed the effect of the new policy on their working conditions."
v. Means to produce a result, or to cause something to happen. For example, "the CEO claimed that the new policy would effect a positive economic outcome."

The use of "effect" as a verb is less common than the use of "affect", and there are usually alternatives that are clearer. For example, "the CEO claimed that the new policy would produce a positive economic outcome."

formalpara.title: Assure, Ensure, and Insure
formalpara.para: These are relatively easy to get right, but here are some quick definitions.

listitem.para: v. Suggests mental comfort. For example, "I assured my future father-in-law that I would eventually find a job."
v. Means to make sure of something, to be certain that something exists or some condition has been met.
